awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Structural dynamics and mechanisms of photoreceptor signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Photoreceptors enable organisms to mediate a vast range of biological responses to light, including photosynthesis, cell and organelle motility, visual transduction and circadian rhythms. These important cellular mediators are implicated in biofilm formation and can alter the virulence of organisms. Photoreceptors are also the prototype for light driven devices. Elucidating the underlying mechanisms of operation of photoreceptors remain a key driver for the development of the field of optogenetics. In most cases, the absorption of light results in chemical and structural changes of the proteins involved that ultimately produce the biological output. Despite extensive studies, many of the details of how this signal is propagated are poorly understood. The objective of this project is to determine the underlying molecular mechanisms that couple light absorption to the activation of downstream biological processes in a specific class of photoreceptors. This work will generate the first time-resolved molecular description of the dynamic transition between states for the Blue Light Using Flavoprotein (BLUF) class of proteins and by providing structural tools that will enable more efficient and effective serial crystallography experiments. The educational objective of this project is to generate a hybrid research/educational structural proteomics pipeline, involving groups of undergraduates and high school students. This crowd-sourcing program will not only provide an opportunity for groups of students to conduct hands-on, 'real' research in a controlled setting, but will leverage the strength in numbers to address a challenging and fundamentally important research problem. The research and educational objectives will be integrated through their parallel use of X-ray crystallography and through graduate student involvement and oversight in both aspects of the proposed work.


The research objective of this project is to determine the intrinsic molecular determinants and dynamic structural features that drive structural changes and signaling events in blue-light using FAD (BLUF) proteins. In particular, the molecular changes that drive signal transduction during the dark to light transition will be elucidated and the mechanism of photo-induced complexation of specific BLUF receptor proteins and complexes will be determined. These studies will integrate time-resolved spectroscopic methods with static and dynamic structural characterization to map the spatial and temporal changes that occur during photoreceptor activation. In addition, an acoustically-mediated serial crystallography approach will be developed and implemented. This approach will be used to generate molecular movies of the structural changes that occur during signal transduction in BLUF proteins and will be broadly applicable as a means to conduct efficient time-resolved structural studies on a broad range of samples at any X-ray source.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Light is essential for most forms of light on earth, and organisms have developed specialized processes to sense and respond to light. Proteins called photoreceptors can detect incoming light and send signals throughout the organism. In humans, photoreceptors help us to see, while in plants and bacteria, these proteins can be used to direct movement towards, or away from light, among other functions. The primary function of the photoreceptor is to convert the incoming light into a signal that activates other molecules, which ultimately lead to the desired output. The overarching goal of this project was to understand how one particular class of photoreceptors can transmit the incoming light into a functionally relevant output.

There are many different types of photoreceptors that are responsible for converting the input light into a signal. Here, we studied Blue Light Using FAD (BLUF) and Light Oxygen Voltage (LOV) photoreceptors of bacteria and fungi. These proteins help control many processes, usually through their effect on the expression of certain sets of genes that are needed for a particular function. Examples include the BLUF photoreceptor AppA, from the purple bacterium Rhodobacter sphaeroides, which helps to control photosynthesis; the LOV photoreceptor YtvA, from the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, helps respond to environmental stress; the fungal BLUF photoreceptor, PixD, is involved in controlling movement towards light; and the BLUF photoreceptor BlsA, from the pathogenic organism Acinetobacter baumannii, is involved in regulating many processes such as the uptake of iron from the environment and the formation of biofilms. In addition to their normal functions, scientists have begun to use photoreceptors as tools to control the function and timing of chemical and physical processes. These tools can be used as switches for the study of biological and biochemical phenomena, and are being tested as a way to develop light-activated medicines and other therapies.

We used a combination of techniques to study several BLUF and LOV proteins. At the core of this research was understanding the molecular structure of the proteins of interest and using the knowledge of the structure to understand how the light signals were transmitted through the proteins and on to other proteins. We used the techniques of X-ray crystallography and Cryo-Electron Microscopy to determine the precise 3-dimensional organization of the molecules within these proteins. By doing these types of experiments under varying conditions, such as when exposed to light over a series of time points, we are able to determine precise details about how the incoming light changes certain parts of the protein and how these changes are transmitted. These studies have extended our understanding of how this class of photoreceptor function and will be a valuable resource for the development of new light-activated molecular tools.

While conducing this research on photoreceptors, this program provided an opportunity for training for numerous undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, we developed and implemented a student-driven pipeline of structural biology research. This led to the launch of a new virtual Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. This 10-week summer research program, called Molecular Interactions Virtual REU (MIV-REU), provides online research opportunities for undergraduate students who face barriers to participation in conventional in-person programs. Over 40 students have participated in the MIV-REU program to date. In addition to valuable research experience, student participants report growth in science identity, confidence, soft skills development, and an increase in their interest in pursuing a career in the sciences.
